reviewText: This is one of the most fluid yoga routines I have found. Rodney Yee's verbal guidance keeps you moving through a continuous sequence of postures, but there is enough quietude (with just a soupcon of background music) to maintain a restful mind as you practice.To me, the title "Power Yoge" suggests a strenuous routine, but the subtitle, "Total Body Workout", is right on the mark. This is not a difficult workout, but it will give a very deep stretch. I felt expanded and more flexible afterward.An excellent yoga workout with Rodney Yee.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Great yoga workout. A good amount of time spent in downward dog pose so if you don't like blood rushing to your head, don't get it. Otherwise, great workout.
Title: N/A

reviewText: but a great Yoga DVD for those with some experience.Yee does not spend a lot of time on alignment, which can be dangerous for beginners.  The comment on feeling it in the "lower back" from a couple of reviewers is a red flag right there.  Not that one cannot have some normal soreness in that region, but busting out Yoga poses without proper instruction can easily lead to lower back strain.  So if you're new to Yoga, I would look elsewhere.Those of you with some experience, Yee's practice starts out slow, but it's a nice way to warm up.  He gradually builds.  I'm a fan of Bryan Kest, Shiva Rea and Baron Baptiste, and I would say Yee's practice is as vigorous.  Not a lot of variety here, but sometimes it's good to pull back and really work a few poses in detail.  I was tired afterwards!He does move a little too fast for me in the seated poses ~ I like to linger and sink in ~ so that's the reason I gave it 4 out of 5.  Kest is great for letting you hang in a pose, so now I resent it when I'm not allowed to do so.Beginners, look into Yoga Journal's Basics DVDs.  The alignment instruction is great.  After that and maybe spending a little time at an Anusara or Iyengar studio, by all means...pick up this DVD.  :oD
summary: Like others have said ~ not for beginners...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I opened this box and played this DVD and wow! The instructions are good, the exercises are fast-paced and challenging, and the music is rather nice. The scenery in the video is very natural, and Rodney Yee is just amazing. I'm just stunned by his flexibility, strength, and expertise. This is highly recommended for the intermediate or advanced beginner, as it provides a powerful workout. The workout is designed so that the yogi can move smoothly and logically from one position to the next. I like the Gaiam videos so far because they're put together wonderfully, very professional, universal, and they take stress out of the day rather than adding to it. I like how they help you to progress at your own pace and offer detailed instructions on how to maneuver properly, whereas you might hurt yourself with a different brand. This was a good buy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have had this particular dvd for quite some time- more than 2 years.  Rodney Yee's Total Body Workout is a graceful power yoga practice that will enhance your well-being and create superior endurance, strength & flexibility. I have been practicing yoga on & off since 1998 but have almost exclusively taken up my practice to include yoga (3x/week vinyasa/power) and walking (3x/week) for the past 6 months.  I was into strenuous aerobics & weight training for the better part of a decade and was feeling really burned out & just constantly tired (physically & mentally).  I always knew that yoga would center me and create a feeling of inner peace but was pushing myself to the limit with hard core workouts that left me unsatisfied.Now I practice my yoga and have not only enhanced my fitness level but feel grounded and present in my everyday life.  Nothing will make me go back to torturing myself through workouts again.  I'm leaner, stronger, more toned and most importantly, I feel finally happy in my own skin.  Yoga has become more than exercise but a way of life. I alternate Rodney Yee's DVD, Bryan Kest's Power Yoga trilogy & anything from Shiva Rea for an unbelievable fit body & mind. Namaste, everyone!
summary: Works in unison with the breath for a great workout!

Do not take the title of this dvd to mean that he has combined his three videos of strength, flexibility and stamina into one dvd (he hasn't), this is just a good dvd to have in your collection.

The only thing I don't like about Rodney Yee's videos is they don't feel very organic and come off a bit too perfect. it is just him doing Yoga on a bluff in Hawaii, which is a cool setting, but I think I like videos where there is a class going on as you are being guided through a practice. reviewText: This one-hour routine is definitely a challenge. It is not for beginners. You must know the poses already and know how to modify if you can't do them like the instructor. I usually don't like Power Yoga, but my sister let me borrow it because she liked it. I like the flow speed and long holding of the poses, but Rodney Yee doesn't give enough of a pause between the sun salutations to witness. I was challenged by the back bends, and did a couple rounds, but I had to back off at the end. I was very warmed up and flexible and learned slight adjustments to put myself further into the pose. I was not real impressed with the DVD menu selection; you pretty much just run it from beginning to end. The scenery and music were lovely. I wouldn't use this DVD a lot, but it would be a nice one when you have a high energy level and you're ready for the challenge.After using this DVD on several occassions I decided this is really a 5 star!!! Amazon won't let you change the rating once your set it. Definetly not for beginners, but fantastic if you know the basics!!!
summary: A challenge, but definitely not good for beginners.

reviewText: I own 3 other Yee yoga DVD's and this one is by far my favorite.  It is for the more advanced yoga student as the poses are held longer and it takes about 60 minutes to complete the DVD, but those are two reasons it is my favorite.  My legs have gotten much stronger because the poses are held longer than most yoga DVD's, and I love the slower pace as it really works on my flexibility and loosens up my back.  I feel like I am getting a personal lesson in yoga from one of the masters.  Also, I use my workout DVD's in the morning and Rodney never gets on my nerves like other workout people do.  He has a calming effect on me and is pleasant to listen to; I never get tired of hearing him explain how the poses should be done.  With my other workout DVD's, I mute the person and play my own music, and I have never had to do this with Rodney.

reviewText: This is my first of Rodney Yee's dvds. I have been practicing yoga for over 7 years, but typically stick to Ashtanga/Vinyasa flow type practices, as I find Hatha & Iyengar a bit too slow & boring. I was hesitant to try this one, as I know he is known for more of the slow-pased routines. I was surprised to find how much I love this DVD!Taking the time to do this DVD is a special treat I give myself. It's a bit long (65 minutes or so) so it's not something I can commit to everyday, but it is well worth the time when I do. I exercise regularly & am constantly surprised by how much I feel my muscles after each time I complete this practice. It is both challenging & relaxing at the same time - I always finish with a smile on my face & peace in my heart (and a welcome soreness in my thighs!). I would definitely recommend this for people who enjoy yoga for both the fitness/strengthening aspect, as well as the mind/soul connection that yoga & meditation provide. A truly great yogic balance!

reviewText: In my opinion, EVERY Rodney Yee DVD is outstanding. This one is one of his best yet! I own 8 Rodney Yee DVD's! When I really need a good Yoga workout, I reach for this one. Title: N/A

reviewText: I love it when a power yoga workout truly uses interesting combinations of hard standing poses to truly work the entire body in a non-linear manner.  This unfortunately is not the case with Rodney Yee.  Yee masks his lack of practical innovation with bland repetition and overly stylized movements indicative of a person who has tried hard to bring show off dance moves to yoga.  It is easy to create a workout where I do A, B poses, then A, B, C poses, then A, B, C, D poses, etc.  This kills time and creates the illusion of physical transformation through variation on a theme.  There is no question when I do Brian Kest or Baron Baptiste that I truly feel worked out.  I did Yee's Power Yoga for a week, grew bored with it, then placed it at the bottom of my Power Yoga DVD pile.  Even though he is somewhat comprehensive with back bends, plow poses, and upturned bow, his introduction is essentially a time killer of ineffectual gesturing and movements which do very little to stimulate the body.  I will say this is Yee's best DVD.  At least he's not insulting my intelligence as he has on virtually every other workout of his that I own.  For power yoga, if you want to feel strong, sweaty, and energized, Yoga Zone, Brian Kest and Baron Baptiste blow Yee away.  This phenomenon proves that being a show off and making a million products does not mean quality is part of the consumer equation.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have used two power yoga videos, one from Bryan Kest, and this one. And I much, much prefer this one. While I cannot yet do all of the poses, particularly the back bends, I can do the others well enough to get a fantastic stretching and even muscle toning workout. I don't see how anyone could get bored in any of the poses, and sometimes would even prefer to hold some of the passive stretches longer--so I pause the DVD and do just that! The entire presentation is exactly what my title says: Challenging enough to hold up to repeated viewings, yet wonderfully relaxing with Yee's controlled voice, presentation and pacing. You'll need to be in shape, yes, to do the entire program, but what a great goal to aim for!

Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this DVD based on the reviews and because I have his other Power Yoga workouts and enjoy them.  I was very disappointed in this DVD.  Like another reviewer, I was expecting some more challenging poses.  All I got were the same few poses over and over again.  Yes, it was hard.  Very hard.  But boring at the same time.  If that makes sense?It was too difficult for me to continue without stopping, and I am somewhere around intermediate in my yoga skill level.  But yet I was so bored I just wanted to stop.  I would think to myself "this pose AGAIN?"So here is my list of pros and cons:Pros:Very challenging, for intermediate or advanced studentsBeautiful settingBasic yoga poses, nothing too out thereCons:Very repetitiveFew of the more challenging, interesting posesToo hard for most people, I think.  He holds the poses quite a long time.I didn't care for the musicYou will like this DVD if you like to do the same poses over and over again.  The first 30 minutes basically consisted of Warrior 1, Warrior 2, push up position, upward facing dog, downward facing dog, standing forward bend.  Over and over again.The rest was a little more varied, but still only common poses.  You will not like this video if you are looking for different kinds of poses, or if you do not have a whole lot of strength already.  This is not for beginners.I'd recommend instead:Intermediate video for women - Yoga Conditioning for Women, 60 minutes.Power yoga - Power Yoga: Stamina (Rodney Yee), 20 minutes.Beginner yoga - Stress Relief Yoga (Suzanne Deason), 20 minutes.
summary: I am a fan of Rodney Yee, but this was disappointing. Very repetitive.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rodney Yee has a careful, meditative style that is very relaxing.  He weaves standing poses into the vinyasa flow (somewhat like Total Yoga - Fire) so that you really maintain heat and deep breathing while doing the deeper stretches.  This session feels very natural, challenging and energizing you without exhausting any single part of the body.  Because of Rodney's precision and calmer pace, you are able to challenge yourself in a particularly relaxing atmosphere.  As Baron Baptiste says, our stress-relievers can be a little bit stressful, and Rodney does a good job of reducing the hyped-up atmosphere that can infiltrate some power yoga videos.  Definitely recommended.
summary: A Complete Yoga Session From Rodney Yee

reviewText: I've never really done Yoga before, but I'm in very good shape and exercise regularly.  I was able to get through the entire exercise without any problem.  However, it is about 60 minutes and gets a little boring.  The menu doesn't offer any chapters to choose from so you have to forward past the things you don't want to do which gets annoying. What I didn't like about Total Body Workout was there was not any instruction on how to do the moves correctly.  I really had no idea what Rodney was talking about and he uses words for body parts that I don't even know where or what they are.  I also found that doing this DVD with out proper instructions can be very dangerous for your lower back.  After doing the workout a couple of times my lower back was very sore.  I've had back problems before so I'm weary of doing this workout more until I learn how to do the all the moves properly.  Overall, it's a pretty good workout, but I would not recommend it for beginners.

reviewText: I  own three of Yee's DVDs (Power Yoga the complete Workout, Yoga for Athletes, and this one), and Yee has not let me down yet.  Each DVD is a little better than the last.  This one may be his best yet.  I think this DVD is a great intermediate level workout.  The level of poses is not extremely complex, but he gives you a complete body workout in about 63 minutes.  Those of you familiar with Yee's "Power Yoga the complete workout" will note that this work out goes 60+ minutes straight, versus breaking up the workout into three types (stamina, strength, and flexibility).  This workout will build endurance for sure.  I like how this DVD is a little less rushed than the first Power Yoga DVD.  The poses are held longer, and are slightly more difficult than the first DVD, but the pace is slower.  In this DVD you may feel less rushed than you did in the previous Power Yoga DVD with moving from one pose to the next.  If you are new to Yoga, this may be tough for you.  Although these poses may or may not be difficult for everyone, the sequence and the amount of time you spend doing them may be.  I would suggest this tape for anyone looking to establish an at home practice who has practiced for at least 6 months or better, and who wants to build endurance.  As I stated before Rod Yee comes through yet again with another great yoga DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This DVD is not for beginners in that there are no modifications offered and you have to be familiar with the pose names as he calls them out one after another.  The beginning of the workout felt choppy and I almost wanted to stop the DVD. I was expecting more of a flow.  The Sun Salutations are not your standard and I think the flow is somewhat compromised.But, I hung in there and worked up a sweat about mid-way,...then it dissipated. I'm used to Bryan Kest and Baron Baptiste's yoga style where you hold the poses longer, and thus generate heat. I'm not saying that there are not challenging poses mixed in, because there are some challenging poses such has half moon and some good back bending poses such as wheel (3xs) and camel, but the rest was average.  Rodney seems to like going from staff pose to cobbler back and forth over and over again and I'm not sure why.  Perhaps it adds some additional grounding.  For me, it disrupted the flow and was a bit annoying.On the positive, his directions are exceptional.  However, you have to hold the pose long enough to benefit, and for the most part, this was just not the case. Given the title "Power Yoga: Total Body Workout", I expected to work up much more a sweat...and hence only 3 stars.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I purchased this video without knowing what to expect.  It is a longer workout but its pace and style is nothing like the Power Yoga for beginners at all. It has its merits for those who have done the AM/PM Yoga and the Beginner one. This is a good one to get once you have gotten the hang of the other DVDs.Rodney Yee has a careful, meditative style that is very relaxing. He weaves standing poses into the vinyasa flow (somewhat like Total Yoga - Fire) so that you really maintain heat and deep breathing while doing the deeper stretches. It starts out slow and then builds up to where you are sweating and feeling the workout throughout your body. His routine is different in his sun salutations which was a nice surprise because if you've done them enough they can be so predictable. The variety was welcome. Also the floor work was different by moving from one stretch to another rather quickly but afterwards you feel loosened up, strengthened and relaxed. This session feels very natural, challenging and energizing you without exhausting any single part of the body. Because of Rodney's precision and calmer pace, you are able to challenge yourself in a particularly relaxing atmosphere. As Baron Baptiste says, our stress-relievers can be a little bit stressful, and Rodney does a good job of reducing the hyped-up atmosphere that can infiltrate some power yoga videos.After a few days of doing this video, I felt really strong throughout my upper and lower body. I also moved better than I have in years. Go on, buy it, you'll feel better! Defiantly recommend.
summary: Wonderful and challenging workout from Rodney
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just tried this video, and I was completely exhausted fifteen minutes into it -- which surprised me because I'm familiar with the poses.  However, they are held for quite a while, then repeated over and over.Unlike many other Gaiam videos, this one isn't divided up into definite sections that can easily serve as self-contained practices.  It *is* divided into "chapters" which are only accessible by fast forwarding, not from the menu. Nor is there any indication on the video itself of the beginning or ending of a section -- it just looks like a single, hour-long session.Ironically, I found that I can do the final two sections, even though some of the poses are more difficult.  But I'm familiar with how to modify or substitute poses(e.g. doing Bridge instead of Upward Bow). Anyone unfamiliar with that is likely to get frustrated -- unless, of course, they are already in very good shape.  This is not a video for beginners.But this would be a good DVD for someone who enjoys a vigorous workout.  I plan to keep on working with it, to challenge myself.

Title: N/A

reviewText: This DVD will give you a great workout and has something to offer yogis of all levels, including coordinated beginners.  It is helpful if you already have some yoga experience before doing this DVD--if you don't know your downward dogs from your Warrior 1, you may be confused and Yee does transition from one move to another quickly, however, as with most yoga practices, the moves repeat and you will soon catch on if you give it a chance.The setting of this DVD is a gorgeous mountain view.  It offers an introduction, 4 chapters which play seamlessly without headings--great if you want to do the whole DVD at once, not so great if you just want to sneak in a short workout.  There is a bonus interview--it was interesting to learn that Yee comes from a ballet background--explaining some of his amazing flexibility, strength, and coordination.  (Yoga is great for dancers of all disciplines!)Overall, this is one of the better workout DVDs out there and I highly recommend it for anyone who would like to improve their flexibility and balance while getting a little relaxation in at the same time.I've done a lot of workout DVDs, and this is one of the few that I'd actually recommend buying!
summary: Something to offer yogis of all levels, worth buying for sure!

reviewText: Rodney Yee is one of the best Yoga instructors out there and so I knew this would be a good dvd that is taught by an experienced and very qualified instructor.  It's a great workout and you don't have to be overly advanced in yoga to do this, because you can do the first half, or keep going if you are up to it.  He has a calm way of cuing (it's done as a voice over but in a nice pleasant way) and he has used an excellent setting - Hawaii (for some reason I find this also adding to the relaxation factor).For the beginners the first half uses easier poses like downward dog and the sun salutations and the advanced people can do the more challenging section which includes moves like upward bow and a standing back bend.  The stretch at the end is fantastic and you come away feeling nice and relaxed yet like you have done a great workout.  I have had this for over a year now, but I still like to do it once a week if I have time.  It's a fantastic way to end the working day or the end of a stressful week.  I love it.

Title: N/A

reviewText: I purchased this DVD along with Brian Kest's "Power Yoga 1, 2, & 3". I'm fairly new to yoga, but athletic so I have no problems getting into the poses or with flexability-and have taken yoga courses outside of these videos.The Good: Yee's delivery is spot on for what I want. Clear, solid, and calm. The workout moves between easier poses quickly, and lingers on other-more difficult poses... perfect. After this video I feel clear and calm. There is a good 10 minute warm up, 20 minutes of some balancing poses, and then about 10 minutes worth of nice hip-openers to cooldown. I like the flow of this dvd... it's got a great rhythm, easy to get into. It's very helpful that Yee uses the traditional English names for the poses (EG. triangle pose, extended-angle pose, bow pose, etc). These are the names your most likely to hear in another video or studio, so when he calls out the next pose-you know exactly what to expect.Nuetral: At times, Yee describes the poses in terms that newer practitioners won't understand. "EXAMPLE: Form an arch from the root of your sacrum to the crown of your head" and so forth. I understand where these parts of my body are, but that doesn't mean I can "feel" what he's describing mid-pose. No matter, I just discard this information and continue. At times the voice narration is behind the onscreen demonstration... only a problem if your watching the TV instead of doing the poses.The Bad: My real complaints here are that (1) the workout feels somewhat short at around 40 minutes, and (2) isn't that challenging-apart from the three upward bows in sequence. I generally use this DVD on days when I don't want the more rigorous [but stunted flowing] workouts provided by Brian Kests "Power Yoga" series.The Verdict: This is a solid purchase and I get a lot of use from the DVD. I really enjoy Yee's flow, instruction, and delivery. I feel very calm and refreshed after completing this routine. On the downside, the workout feels "incomplete"... as if Yee left 20 minutes worth of poses on the cutting room floor.
summary: Yee: a good teacher, but a workout that leaves something on the table...

reviewText: My primary reasons for taking up yoga were to lose weight, reallign my back, increase flexibility, and achieve more relaxed breathing. Yee's Total Body Workout, a little over an hour, achieves all my goals. First, let me say you need to have about six months of basic yoga in order to do these moves and you probably can't be more than thirty pounds overweight; many of the moves require a body that is reasonably muscular. I've got six months of yoga and thirty years of bodybuilding (both a blessing and a curse) behind me so I can do 90% of the moves. Secondly, you should invest in a thick yoga mat; they go for about forty dollars and if you sweat a lot like I do, place a beach towel over the mat so you don't slip. The only other piece of equipment you might need is a ten-dollar strap or just a belt for some of the lying leg stretches.I like Yee's screen persona. He is authentic, direct, and clear. He spares you New Age pretentiousness, self-aggrandizement, and any other affectations.The workout is vigorous and fast-paced. For the first five minutes, a warm-up period, you think you're going to get off with an easy workout but within twenty minutes you're sopping with sweat. The first couple of times you might just have to figure out what Yee is doing. By the third workout, you should be able to follow along seamlessly. It's worth the work. You'll burn between 500-700 calories per workout; that's over a pound of fat a week or fifty-two pounds a year.On a more subtle note, I've noticed my breathing is more relaxed throughout the day and there appears to be a connection between relaxed breathing and less consumption of food. I've always been cursed with a voracious appetite, and while my daily hour of yoga hasn't totally cured it, my hungers are lower, I'd say 10% less than without the yoga.Also with bodybuilding and cardio at the gym, I come home exhausted and must nap for a good hour before I can do anything productive. With yoga, I don't need a nap. I'm already energized.It's important to change your yoga workouts so you don't go stale. I'd recommend checking out the Bryan Kest DVDs, especially his Power Yoga, which has three workouts on one DVD.
Title: N/A

I thought this would be easy...it's not.  You need to be somewhat flexible and have some stamina to get thru this routine. It flows very nicely without hesitation. reviewText: I purchased this DVD three years ago and, although I own many yoga DVDs, "Power Yoga: Total Body Workout" and "Total Energy Yoga," another Yee DVD, are the ones to which I keep returning.  "Power Yoga" is, as advertised, an excellent, total body workout -- albeit not one for beginners -- with just the right amount of instruction and no irritating "pep talks" or celebrity prattling: in other words, real yoga.Most positions are held for 30 seconds, although a few are held for shorter periods of time and one --upward bow -- is repeated three times in a row.  Sufficient time is permitted for transfer from one position to the next, even if, in the beginning, a practitioner cannot maintain  the "flow" and needs to walk from one position to another.  In my view, Yee is, along with Shiva Rea, the best yoga instructor making DVDs, and "Power Yoga" is his best DVD, overall.One additional note:  Recently, I have been employing this yoga practice and Yee's "Total Energy Yoga" along with physical therapy to treat a "frozen shoulder".  My physical therapist is impressed by the progress that I have made using these yoga DVDs.  While I would never suggest that anyone -- especially someone with an injury -- try an exercise DVD without first consulting his or her doctor, I have to say that yoga and, specifically, Rodney Yee, has worked for me.

reviewText: I generally like power yoga, but I agree that this tape is too repetitive and overall boring.  There are so many other poses that could have been incorporated into the workout to keep it from becoming monotonous.  I also don't like that there are no modifications - I'd love to be as flexible as Rodney Yee, but I'm not there yet.  A much better workout is Bryan Kest's Power Yoga DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This yoga video incorporates strength, stamina and flexiblity for a great (as the title implies)total body workout. I have found other yoga videos to be too short, but the complete Total Body Workout is over an hour long which is good for a challenge. The routine starts with simple movements to warm you up, and then gradually adds more strenuous movement and poses. The routine ends with stretching and relaxation poses. My favorite yoga dvd to date.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are familiar with postures and sun salutations and don't need to be talked through the pose, this is for you. It gets right to the point and you get right into it. It starts in mountain and goes through the sun salutations gently and then incorporates warrior 1,2 3 and side angles and then gets into back bends and seated postures. I wouldn't call it so much of a power dvd as I would a total body dvd. The only thing missing was some inversions but definitely enjoyable all together.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have been practicing yoga regularly for about three years, and found this dvd to be a wonderful addition to my practice. Most of the poses are simple enough so that they can be attained by beginners, however, the length of the practice and the quantity of standing poses makes for a vigorous workout. This one is not for everyone however, I was a professional athlete and continue to stay in good shape, and I found myself (after the first couple of practices) to really feel the workout in my back. If you have not done a lot of yoga, you may want to start with a less strenuous tape, however if you like to feel a deep stretch and don't mind a few sore muscles, this is the yoga tape for you.
Title: N/A

reviewText: After reading a lot of the complaints I was wondering if I had the right DVD! But in today's hi-tech, have it now, gotta do it perfect the first time society, I suppose there will always be complainers.I found this DVD to be an excellent addition to my work out. I am a beginner and although some of the positions can be difficult, especially for us middle and upper agers, it is not that hard to get through and I am finding that I am getting better the more I do it (as are all good things in life!)It is not, and I can't imagine any style of yoga is, a replacement for biking, running, martial arts, weight lifting, etc. It is a compliment to all sports and health. I do it as an alternative to stretching. It is a single way to move all of the muscles in the body; to help loosen my muscles and get the kinks out.It is an hour but I find the music and scenery very pleasing and help me to relax. Although he has a bit of an accent I find him easy to follow and listen to.

reviewText: I'm in pretty good shape (I do triathlons) and I found this video extremely challenging.  Other classes and videos have put me to sleep.  This one incorporates a lot of strength moves and left me very "worked-out".  He never sits down for the first 45 minutes so your heart beat stays up. I highly recommend this video if you want a work out from your yoga-and don't care to have your chakras aligned for you.

reviewText: If anyone would have asked me if I would be doing yoga 10 to 20 years ago..I would have thought they were crazy, but here I amdoing yoga and loving it. I'm 44 yrs of age and just wanted to get into something good and beneficial instead of the local gyms that I was accustomed too.I bought some yoga dvd's based on some of Yoga dad's reviews on amazon.com and I've been hooked ever since. I started with AM/PM yoga w/ Rodney Yee which was a great starting point for me and have moved onto Power Yoga - Total Body Workout w/ Rodney Yee.At first I could only complete 30 minutes into the one hour workout, but after 1 week I completed the full hour.This is a great dvd, for anyone to get into shape and feel relaxed. Rodney Yee has a soft voice which comes across very clear. The scenery and music in the back ground is great.NamasteYoga123

reviewText: This video is great. I'm a beginner and I found this video to be just perfect for me. A lot of the spine exercises were challenging and I'm not really able to do it. But that's the beauty of the video. It's simple enough for beginners but also challenging enough that you're not bored. Just do what you can and with time, the sustained poses become more easy. And it's quite a workout. I'm usually wiped out by the end.

reviewText: I am a fan of Rodney Yee's yoga dvds and find him to be a very knowledgeable instructor whose style isn't too heavily focused on the mental/spiritual side of yoga OR the purely physical side, but rather offers a nice balance between the two. This dvd is one of his best in my opinion.This is definitely a vinyasa yoga dvd, meaning that the movements flow one into the other fluidly so no one position is "held". That's not to say that there aren't some sections where he holds certain stretches, but overall I found this to be much more in the vinyasa style than his other dvds. You go through a Sun Salutation sequence several times throughout the practice.I found this to be one of his more advanced dvds, aimed toward those with at least some yoga experience. Beginners could do this as well, but may need to work up to some of the movements and watch the dvd before trying it. The most difficult poses are probably a full back bend (upward bow) and some balancing poses like half moon and warrior 3. I enjoyed that this dvd got my whole body temp up as each muscle felt both strengthened and stretched through the repetition and flow of poses.If you're a fan of yoga, Rodney Yee is one of the best instructors, and this dvd is arguably my favorite of his.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ...which is exactly why I bought this DVD and I love it! I'd started off with Rodney Yee's Yoga for Beginners DVD and after about a month's practice with it wanted to graduate to a tougher workout. Initially I found the DVD extremely hard (on the first day I couldn't go beyond 20 minutes). As others have stated, it is not a beginner-level workout and ideally I should have picked up one of Yee's other DVDs. But this was the only 60 minute workout by Rodney Yee that I could find. Make sure you familiarize yourself with what the poses entail (for which I recommend the Beginners' DVD) before you begin.But bit by bit, with regular practice I found my strength and stamina going up. By the end of the second week I could do the entire 60 minutes, albeit with modifications. I am in my second month now and though still hard, I have started enjoying the workout.Of course, I still rely on modifications, for instance, I do the bridge pose instead of upward bow; modified camel instead of camel; when I take my leg up they're bent (not straight like Rodney's) etc. etc. But in the first month, with my thoughts along the lines of "aaaaah I'd rather be doing the dishes"(a much despised chore), I was at a whole different level! But I digress. My point is that even if you aren't a seasoned practitioner, stick with the DVD and with time you will get stronger. Just remember to not push yourself too hard.On another note, I love the background music though it took a while to grow on me. As for the sequence - the first 30 minutes consists of mountain pose, forward bend, plank, push-up, up/down dog followed by warrior two/triangle/extended side angle/warrior one/half-moon/warrior 3. Yes, it can get repetitive but personally I enjoy the repetitive-ness! The latter half has back-bends,camel,upward bow, some seated bends and twists among others.And finally a word about the instructor - Rodney Yee is amazing. After a couple of times, I didn't even need to look at the screen as his instructions were spot-on. He doesn't really give a breakdown of the poses, but does give valuable tips that help in safe and effective execution of the poses.I just wish Gaiam and Rodney Yee would incorporate the matrix technology in their DVDs. I am now looking for an alternative for variety. All other Rodney Yee DVDs have multiple 20-minute practices which seems to be the format in demand. But they are difficult to use for a longer practice without the matrix.
summary: An hour long, repititive, tough workout...
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a 60 min workout in the usual beautiful landscapes of Hawaii that Gaiam is known for. Rodney Yee's soothing, but strong, never boring voice overs lets you know when to inhale/exhale, subtle body reminders of each pose & the English pose name. The poses are held for a moderate amount of time, enough to get into it w/awareness, hold it for 2 breaths & get out gracefully so you don't hold it so long those that bore easily would get bored, but long enough to actually feel the stretch & the muscles reacting to the poses. The music is mostly piano based, too fast in my taste until after some of the standing poses & then I warmed up to it more. You cannot change voice over or music choices at all.There aren't any mentu options other then to skip the menu. There are only a few bookmarks to skip to, such as at the 20 min mark, & 42 min mark.Intro - 3 minWarm-up to/before full sun salutations - 5 min (in/out from mountain to standing fwd bends, back/froth from standing fwd bent/lunges.Sun Salutations - 5 min - w/warrior 1Standing Poses - 22 min - w/sun salutations in between almost all the poses, when I do this workout again, I will most likely skip the first 10 min to avoid being bored by repetition. SS = Sun Salutation. Warrior 2, triangle, warrior 2, SS, same on other side, SS 2x, 3 legged down dog, warrior 2, side angle, warrior 2, SS, same on other side, SS, SS w/chair pose, warrior 1, SS, other side, SS w/chair, warrior 2, side angle, triangle, half moon, triangle, warrior 2, up & down dog, other side, SS w/chair 2x, warrior 1, warrior 3, warrior 1, up & down dog, standing wide angle, pyramid both sides, down dog, crescent, same on other side, sphinx, SSSitting/Lying Poses - 23 min - SS, bow, up & down dog, warrior 1, down dog, same on other side, hero w/torso stretch, camel, upward bow/wheel 3x, reclined foot to hand 1 position only on both sides, reclined foot to hand w/lifted head, reclined crossed leg over knee & then to chest both sides, rocking on spine, cobbler's w/alternate staff 3x w/butterfly, seated wide angle fwd bend, cobbler's, seated single leg fwd bend on both sides, butterfly, seated wide angle fwd bend, cobbler's, boat, staff, half lotus seated spinal twist both sides, staff, seated straight fwd bend, reclined knee to side spinal twist both sidesSavasana/Relaxation - 5 min - 3 min reclined w/guided meditation, 2 min seated in lotus w/guided meditationI detest repetition, especially with sun salutations & some of the in/out of the 2 poses in the sitting poses, but when there was a few poses before redoing a pose such as wide angle, I noticed I was much more flexible.Preview on youtube under "Power Yoga Total Body Workout" by GaiamSearch
summary: Not aerobic fast Power Yoga, but good for advanced beginners/intermediates

reviewText: The sixty minute class starts with a gentle warm up that wakens every inch of your body and mind using easy salutations.  You then seamlessly progress to a vigorous standing series that flows in and out of a variety of poses in a delightfully unexpected and surprising helpful way.  Concentration is key here if you want to tap into your deeper strength, balance and alignment.  RY then moves you to the floor for an unusual and smoothly continuous series of stretches, core strengtheners, backbends and twists (no inversions) before leading you through a much needed relaxation finish.The spectacular setting helps set your mood when you first watch the DVD to become familiar with the routine before doing it.  RY's beautifully melodic, calm and non-judgmental voice makes it easy to establish a focused and even meditative state of concentration. Once actually in the class, RY's instruction and cueing are perfect; I've done the class three times now and find I do not need to look at the screen at all (unless I want to, of course) because he leads you through everything so well.The poses themselves are not new or particularly challenging for a practiced yogi.  However, the unusual, continuous flow and tempo of the sequences demand your complete concentration if you want to do the asanas correctly.  This might be too much for a complete beginner but is very satisfying for an intermediate.A brilliantly choreographed lesson.  RY has an excellent technique that somehow finds your hidden focus and abilities, and draws them out in a truly satisfying way.  The sequences build from vinyasa to vinyasa in flows that are perfectly designed to challenge and develop your concentration and technique.
summary: A thorough and invigorating intermediate class that helps you reach into every corner of your body and breath.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've been doing this workout every morning for the last 12 months and can definitely say Rodney Yee's Power Yoga Total Body Workout is the best out there for me.  I've lost 50 pounds, am stronger, more alert, yet calmer than before I started.  I cannot explain why, but I went from having chronic allergies to having none at all.  My dentist also claims I found a cure for gum disease.  I assume this is from the breathing.  After starting this program I searched and bought several workout DVDs to mix it up with this one. My complaints were always the same.  Either the teacher talked too much or they were incredibly slow.  I am interested in the philosophy behind Yoga but save all that for bonus features.  Don't tell me while I'm stuck in Downward Dog for five minutes.  I wanted a fairly even paced, rigorous  flow with poses that worked the whole body.  Rodney Yee created the best I have found.I've read some reviews that state this is not for beginners.  Of course a beginner like I was will not do every pose, or in my case all the poses perfectly.  I was not a flexible person but can now do every pose correctly.  I have torn cartilage in my knee so a couple of poses (the lotus series) are impossible.  The secret is to stick with it and the pose will come.  I have now modified the ending a bit to include a few poses from Astanga, inversions, and more half boat poses.  My only criticism is that Yee does not do enough work on the abs.The workout is 60 minutes and is a flowing vinyasa sequence that combines Sun Salutations with standing poses, forward bends, back bends, twists, and arm balances for a complete total-body workout.  The workout seems to drag toward the last 10 minutes so I have modified as mentioned above by adding more half boat poses and a few inversions such as shoulder stands.  I highly recommend doing this workout in the morning and have not suffered by getting up earlier to accommodate my work schedule.  I have turned many people on to Yoga as everyone has asked how I lost 50 pounds without changing my diet.  Oh yeah, I am 50 years old.  This was my answer to my mid life crisis. Definitely cheaper than buying a red Porsche.
summary: The Best Yoga Workout Out There
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is the third or fourth yoga DVD that I bought, after I decided to try out yoga to workout instead of running because of a back injury. This is a well-made DVD and challenging workout for a beginner. I found the positions challenging without being too tiring or difficult to do until after about half an hour. Rodney Yee progresses from easier poses to increasingly difficult ones, and I have to stop at about 30 minutes because I haven't developed the strength to do the poses after that mark. Even though I have to cut it short, I still find that I get a really good workout, and I've found that I'm much more toned overall after I started using this DVD and alternating it with my cardio workouts.I highly recommend this for beginners and those looking for overall toning without creating bulkiness.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just bought this video and previewed it. I haven't done it yet, but it looks like a winner.  I only gave it 4 stars because on the back of the video box it mentions arm balances.  There are no arm balances on the video version.  Maybe on the DVD version.  One of the 1st reviewers said that there is a crane pose? Not on the video version.  I was disappointed and annoyed that the video description was incorrect on this matter.  Also on Collagevideo, the review said something about a standing back bend.  Very misleading.  Those of us who take yoga classes thought that meant dropping into upward facing bow from a standing position.  No so.  It just means that you stretch back after finishing a sun saluation. Other than that, the poses are not difficult for any adv. beg./intermediate practitioner.  The best part of the class is going back and forth between staff pose and plow pose.  How wonderful that is for your back! Also, with bow pose you hold your feet from the inside instead of the outside, this appears to give a wonderful stretch to the shoulders.  There are no inversions, arm balances or really challenging poses.  All in all it is good for those of us long time yogis who are short on time, but want to get the kinks out. Looking forward to anything else Rodney does.  He NEVER bombards you with useless chatter like Baron Baptiste or Bryan Kest--NO "repor with the floor" nonsense; just very useful instructions.  Also he great to watch for correct body alignment.
Title: N/A

reviewText: [...]this workout has common yoga poses , it's not so advanced but also not for beginners, of course if you have bad knees some of the postures won't be good for you but so in all types of workouts, this tape isn't dangerous for anyone except for people who don't listen to their bodies! This is a 65 minute power yoga routine which starts with few modified sun salutations and then full ones , it continues with standing poses(including hero 3) and vinyasas between them , and then some backbends,twists ,forward bends and corpse in the end.One problem only- there's no arm balances on this dvd like they mentioned on the cover! The quality is excellent and so is the music, so it's  worth a try.
summary: Good Workout, Beautiful Set, Nice Music

reviewText: Yes this is Rodney and he is lovely and the workout is adequate but I found that, compared to other Gaiam Dvds (of which I own 10 or so) the "cinematography" of this one was quite bland.  I had purchased it having read the reviews here, and did the routine for the first time last night.  Although it is a GOOD and CHALLENGING workout (and indeed much lengthier than others on the market) I just was not inspired and truthfully, got a bit bored.There are so many videos on the market and the one thing I LOVE about the Gaiam series is always the lovely scenery and beautiful music. Let's be honest, that is why we all love the Gaiam series!  I think this one was a rush job because neither were very good. Rodney is on top of a hill the entire time and the music is more elevator than relaxation. As for the workout yes it was decent and thorough (you start with sun salutations and finish with upward arrow in a slow repetitive progression increasing in difficutly), although I found it a bit monotonous through the one single routine and repetitive music which is about 1 hour in length.  Also agree with R Smith comment posted here- the narration is also a bit loud and not as soothing as other Rodney videos.  Basically, something is just a bit off about the presentation of this series.I enjoyed the Rodney Yee Yoga for Strength and Flexi DVD much better and would recommend that one over this one for any one who has trouble "self motivating" and finds the music and scenery an added benefit to the workout regiment.  If that is NOT important to you, however, then I would encourage you to add this to your collection as it would actually be a good DVD to take on holiday with you or when travelling if you need 1 DVD that will give you a good solid hour long workout.  You should be at the intermediate level to complete the entire workout.Namastei.
Title: N/A
